fields.description: The static path should be configurable.

comments.body: [~viglesias] Is this for runapp.py?  Any preference on where the configuration should be set?
For a recommended production deployment, the static path is configured in the nginx.conf file (e.g. at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/blob/develop/conf/nginx.conf#L56)

in 3.4, the package install script added the static.path setting to console.ini. Tornado used that if set.
If we require nginx, because we can't handle that ourselves, we need to bundle nginx and configure it as part of install. (IMHO)

I've enabled configuration of the static path on branch GUI-582, with the relevant commit at 
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/commit/470f5eb7391a2315ff59e99868992b85dbe4d785

However, when I add an absolute path in the console.ini (via static.path=/path/to/eucaconsole/static), I get the following exceptionâ€¦
https://gist.github.com/kamalgill/75ee33bb0b27acf230fb

...which is odd, since allowing absolute folder paths in the static asset config was added to Pyramid 1.2, and we're on 1.4.

I've asked [~Rocky] to help investigate.

The problem here is the asset specification.  Referring to this asset:
${request.static_path('eucaconsole:static/img/favicon.ico')}

This means the asset lives in the static subdir of the eucaconsole package.  When you change the static file mapping to something absolute, that package reference makes no sense.

I'm experimenting with a few ways to make the "eucaconsole:static" reference to map to an arbitrary filesystem path.

After more research, including asking in #pyramid on freenode... it seems there's no simple way to do this.  There's an active pull request to add this functionality to override_asset() that would do exactly what we need.
https://github.com/Pylons/pyramid/pull/1252

It might be possible to hook into the pyramid machinery and do what we want but it would definitely be a lot more work.

[~viglesias]: We're blocked on this since the ability to specify an absolute folder path for the static assets won't land until Pyramid 1.6 (see https://github.com/Pylons/pyramid/issues/1229 and https://github.com/Pylons/pyramid/pull/1252).  Please advise w.r.t. next steps.
One option here is to monkey patch in the changes from that pull request.  I'd estimate a day (8hrs).  Would require some initial testing to how hard the monkey patch will be.
[~viglesias] Could you confirm if this remains a blocker?  If so, we'll need to pursue the monkey-patch approach indicated by [~Rocky]

Can't we use this config? 
config.add_static_view(name='static', path='/var/www/static')

It's found here: http://docs.pylonsproject.org/projects/pyramid/en/1.4-branch/narr/assets.html#serving-static-assets

That's in the 1.4 docs.

Yes but in order to use that static mapping we would have to change each and every one of our templates that use static assets to stop them from using "eucaconsole:static/whatever.png" to "/var/www/statc/whatever.png".

See my two previous comments ... #pyramid on freenode confirmed that there's no way to add this without changing our templates until a submitted PR is pushed into pyramid 1.6

No...

Here's the logic config.add_static_view('static', 'static') registers the static subdir of the existing package (in our case eucaconsole) and marks it *available* for asset serving.  request.static_path('eucaconsole:static/css/pages/volumes.css') says build url for volumes.css.  The "eucaconsole:" portion is just shorthand for saying, "from whatever directory the eucaconsole python package belongs".

So... if you register config.add_static_view(name='static', path='/var/www/static') that just marks /var/www/static as being available for static assets.  The canonical url lookup would have to be request.static_path('/var/www/static/css/pages/volumes.css').  Using request.static_path('eucaconsole:static/css/pages/volumes.css') will error as no static dir of the eucaconsole package was registered.
Given the breadth of the required changes this late in the game, I am okay punting on this until the next maintenance release or when the upstream merges the patch, which ever comes first.
What's the status on this?  It's still labelled a blocker, should I be working on it?
I've been able to get pyramid to serve static assets from a directory outside the package. Trying to nail down how to generate the URLs properly within our templates (request.static_path(...))
